pullRequest.body:
Define the geometrical properties of a simplex (typically a triangle) in a `NormedAddTorsor` being scalene, equilateral or regular, and provide some basic API.  (There is more that could be proved in a Euclidean context - for example, that equilateral and regular are equivalent in that context, and the angles of such a simplex - but this seems like a reasonable start.  There are also more simplex properties to define in a Euclidean context, such as that of being acute-angled.)


---

(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

If you are moving or deleting declarations, please include these lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

- ...

* The `relative` value is the weighted *sum* of the differences with weight given by the *inverse* of the current value of the statistic.
* The `absolute` value is the `relative` value divided by the total sum of the inverses of the current values (i.e. the weighted *average* of the differences).
</details>

Pull request successfully merged into master.

Build succeeded:
  * [Lint style](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/13267526671/job/37038659901)
  * [Build](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/13267526671/job/37038660422)

Just wondering, would this be easier to apply if the latter two assumptions were phrased as `not (i₁ = i₃ \and i₂ = i₄)`. Because then, when proving the assumption, you can immediately `rintro \<rfl, rfl\>`, and work towards a contradiction.
Could you please also provide a version that uses `0`, `1`, and `2 : Fin 3`?
I've added the version with `0`, `1` and `2` in that order (this is an asymmetrical statement, any two equalities suffice out of three).

pullRequest.title: [Merged by Bors] - feat(Analysis/Normed/Affine/Simplex): simplex properties
